body:
That's actually a duplicate of that issue: https://github.com/assertj/assertj-core/issues/2450 with the different output because of used Java version. It happens as well with other classes placed inside of ```java.util.concurrent.atomic.*``` or ```java.util.concurrent.locks.*```

I believe it would be good to find a generic solution to that issue as it can happen not only with JDK classes, right?

I think the only generic solution would be to use `equals` for java types, that is acceptable if `equals` is overridden but it's not the case for `AtomicReference`, the best option here is to have a comparator registered by default for  `AtomicReference` that would compare their value ... recursively.

After more thoughts on this one, I think the only viable solution is to use `equals` for java types by default (even if not overridden) as we can't introspect these types anymore, then for certain types like `Optional` or `AtomicReference` we can compare them by value without introspection (basically accessing their fields through getters).

Why not doing that for all java types? well there are too many to deal with and for some it does not make sens to compare them recursively (for example `ReentrantReadWriteLock`), for these we just rely on `equals`.

issue.title: Java 11 to 17 -> BigDecimal intValue field no longer accessible (JPMS)

labels.name: language: Java 17+
labels.description: An issue related to using AssertJ with Java 17 or newer

repository.name: assertj
repository.description: Fluent testing assertions for Java and the JVM

issue.body:
#### Summary
Hi,

We are migrating our java code from 11 to 17 and use JPMS
With java 11 there was already a warning during running a testscenario where we do:
```java
 assertThat(value)
      .usingRecursiveComparison()
      .ignoringCollectionOrder()
      .isEqualTo(expected);
```

value is containing a BigDecimal and that gives the following warning:

WARNING: An illegal reflective access operation has occurred
WARNING: Illegal reflective access by org.assertj.core.util.introspection.FieldUtils (file:/home/niels/.m2/repository/org/assertj/assertj-core/3.21.0/assertj-core-3.21.0.jar) to field java.math.BigDecimal.intVal
WARNING: Please consider reporting this to the maintainers of org.assertj.core.util.introspection.FieldUtils
WARNING: Use --illegal-access=warn to enable warnings of further illegal reflective access operations
WARNING: All illegal access operations will be denied in a future release

With java 17 the test no longer passes:
org.assertj.core.util.introspection.IntrospectionError: 
Can't find any field or property with name 'intVal'.
Error when introspecting properties was :
- No getter for property 'intVal' in java.math.BigDecimal 
Error when introspecting fields was :
- Unable to obtain the value of the field <'intVal'> from <10.52>


The underlaying error:
Unable to make field private final java.math.BigInteger java.math.BigDecimal.intVal accessible: module java.base does not "opens java.math" to unnamed module @14ec4505

Thrown in PropertyOrFieldSupport -> getSimpleValue-method (fieldsupport.fieldValue(...))

#### Example

Easy way to reproduce the error
```java
assertThat(new BigDecimal("10.52"))
                .usingRecursiveComparison()
                        .isEqualTo(BigDecimal.valueOf(10.52));
```

issue.title: Java Warning: An illegal reflective access operation has occurred when recursive comparison with compiled Regex Pattern

labels.name: theme: recursive comparison
labels.description: An issue related to the recursive comparison

labels.name: language: Java 17+
labels.description: An issue related to using AssertJ with Java 17 or newer

repository.name: assertj
repository.description: Fluent testing assertions for Java and the JVM

issue.body:
#### Summary

I have a test, where I use Mockito Captor to capture the argument for a function of a mocked class.

This function gets an object with a compiled regex pattern inside.

I manually build an expected object on the same way and assert equality with assert4j.

So, everything works fine and the comparison fails, if I change my expected regex, but Java puts out this warning, when running the test:

/usr/lib64/jvm/java-11-openjdk-11/bin/java ...

WARNING: An illegal reflective access operation has occurred
WARNING: Illegal reflective access by org.assertj.core.util.introspection.FieldUtils (file:/..../repository/org/assertj/assertj-core/3.18.1/assertj-core-3.18.1.jar) to field java.util.regex.Pattern.cursor
WARNING: Please consider reporting this to the maintainers of org.assertj.core.util.introspection.FieldUtils
WARNING: Use --illegal-access=warn to enable warnings of further illegal reflective access operations
WARNING: All illegal access operations will be denied in a future release

I am not sure, if it is a problem with org.mongojack.DBQuery (but that's only some value holding object), with Mockito or with assertj, but Java told me, to report it to you :-)  

#### Example

I hope the example gives you a clue, I unfortunately don't have the time, to build an independend and fully working/reproducing example.


```java
import org.mongojack.DBQuery;

...

@Captor
private ArgumentCaptor<DBQuery.Query> queryCaptor;

...

DBQuery.Query expectedFilter = DBQuery.and(
                DBQuery.regex("id", Pattern.compile(".*((?i)aaa123).*", Pattern.CASE_INSENSITIVE)),
                DBQuery.regex("textfeld", Pattern.compile(".*((?i)Haha).*", Pattern.CASE_INSENSITIVE)));
when(mockedClass.someFunction(queryCaptor.capture())).thenReturn("result");

testedClass.doStuff();

assertThat(queryCaptor.getValue()).usingRecursiveComparison().isEqualTo(expectedFilter);

```

issue.title: IntrospectionError on Class/KClass recursive comparison

labels.name: theme: recursive comparison
labels.description: An issue related to the recursive comparison

labels.name: language: Kotlin
labels.description: An issue related to using AssertJ with Kotlin

repository.name: assertj
repository.description: Fluent testing assertions for Java and the JVM

issue.body:
Hi

I encountered an issue with recursive comparison of Java/Kotlin class types. Basically those two tests are failing with the following error:

```
    @Test
    fun test() {
        val a: Any = Integer::class
        val b: Any = Long::class

        assertThat(a).usingRecursiveComparison().isEqualTo(b)
    }

    @Test
    fun test2() {
        val a: Any = Integer::class.java
        val b: Any = Long::class.java

        assertThat(a).usingRecursiveComparison().isEqualTo(b)
    }
```

```
org.assertj.core.util.introspection.IntrospectionError: 
Can't find any field or property with name 'timestamp'.
Error when introspecting properties was :
- No getter for property 'timestamp' in java.lang.ref.SoftReference 
Error when introspecting fields was :
- Unable to obtain the value of the field <'timestamp'> from <java.lang.ref.SoftReference@60b33bc>
	at app//org.assertj.core.util.introspection.PropertyOrFieldSupport.getSimpleValue(PropertyOrFieldSupport.java:88)
	at app//org.assertj.core.api.recursive.comparison.RecursiveComparisonConfiguration.dualValueForField(RecursiveComparisonConfiguration.java:631)
	at app//org.assertj.core.api.recursive.comparison.RecursiveComparisonConfiguration.lambda$getNonIgnoredActualFieldNames$3(RecursiveComparisonConfiguration.java:609)
	at java.base@17.0.8.1/java.util.stream.ReferencePipeline$3$1.accept(ReferencePipeline.java:197)
	at java.base@17.0.8.1/java.util.stream.ReferencePipeline$2$1.accept(ReferencePipeline.java:179)
	at java.base@17.0.8.1/java.util.HashMap$KeySpliterator.forEachRemaining(HashMap.java:1707)
	at java.base@17.0.8.1/java.util.stream.AbstractPipeline.copyInto(AbstractPipeline.java:509)
	at java.base@17.0.8.1/java.util.stream.AbstractPipeline.wrapAndCopyInto(AbstractPipeline.java:499)
	at java.base@17.0.8.1/java.util.stream.ReduceOps$ReduceOp.evaluateSequential(ReduceOps.java:921)
	at java.base@17.0.8.1/java.util.stream.AbstractPipeline.evaluate(AbstractPipeline.java:234)
	at java.base@17.0.8.1/java.util.stream.ReferencePipeline.collect(ReferencePipeline.java:682)
	at app//org.assertj.core.api.recursive.comparison.RecursiveComparisonConfiguration.getNonIgnoredActualFieldNames(RecursiveComparisonConfiguration.java:615)
	at app//org.assertj.core.api.recursive.comparison.RecursiveComparisonDifferenceCalculator.determineDifferences(RecursiveComparisonDifferenceCalculator.java:276)
	at app//org.assertj.core.api.recursive.comparison.RecursiveComparisonDifferenceCalculator.determineDifferences(RecursiveComparisonDifferenceCalculator.java:189)
	at app//org.assertj.core.api.RecursiveComparisonAssert.determineDifferencesWith(RecursiveComparisonAssert.java:1258)
	at app//org.assertj.core.api.RecursiveComparisonAssert.isEqualTo(RecursiveComparisonAssert.java:160)
```

Those are simple examples for reproduction of the issue I encountered it in my code while comparing more complex objects of a class with `KClass` property.

**assertj version:** 3.20.2
